awd_titl_txt: Exploring the relation between non-spatial skills and mental rotation from infancy to preK
awd_abstract_narration:
Mental rotation, the ability to mentally manipulate a visual representation of an object and recognize its appearance from a different orientation, shows stability from infancy through preschool. This ability predicts mathematical achievement in kindergarten and beyond as well as entry into the Science, Technology, Engineering, and Mathematics (STEM) fields. The present work focuses on identifying how non-spatial processes contribute to mental rotation abilities. Findings will help identify ideal time points for intervention, advance understanding of the factors that contribute to mental rotation, and address how individual differences in mental rotation during infancy predict later abilities. This work will involve the creation and refinement of measures that can be used to trace the development of mental rotation from infancy into preschool; thereby, not only contributing new tools to the field, but also yielding insights that can inform current theoretical conceptions of mental rotation and its relation to non-spatial processes. 

The critical research question is as follows: What are the non-spatial processes that contribute to mental rotation abilities and their development?  Associations between mental rotation, object features, processing bias, and motor experience will be examined using a cross-sequential design with overlapping age cohorts. The investigators will recruit an infant cohort at 8 months, a toddler cohort at 20 months, and a preschool cohort at 3 years. Each cohort will be assessed at three time points -- every six months for infants (i.e., 8, 14, and 20 months), every 8 months for toddlers (i.e., 20, 28, and 36 months), and every year for preschoolers (3, 4, and 5 years). When examined at a specific age, the sample will provide a snapshot into the association between mental rotation and non-spatial skills (i.e., object features, processing bias, and motor experience). The longitudinal design will allow the investigators to follow participants across infancy, toddlerhood, or the preschool years. This approach provides an opportunity to understand how non-spatial skills, such as more precocious motor skills during infancy, may shape mental rotation over time. Such findings are central to bolstering understanding of the possible mechanisms by which particular types of experiences can promote infants' mental rotation. This, consequently, has implications for promoting academic achievement and remediating existing discrepancies in spatial and mathematical skills in children from different socioeconomic backgrounds.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
This NSF project examined the development of mental rotation in children between 12 and 48 months. The goals were to document this critical spatial cognitive skill in the period between infancy and preschool age, and to understand how the development of this skill is related to other developing abilities such as memory for object features and fine motor skills. We achieved these goals in a series of studies conducted across Cornell University, UC Davis, and Rutgers University, Newark.

Data from a cross-sectional sample demonstrated how children's ability to insert objects into openings in a shape sorter shifted across the period from 12 to 48 months. Across this age range, children became more efficient at inserting shapes into the correct openings, suggesting changes in the ability to mentally rotate the shapes, to manually manipulate the shapes, and to match shapes to their openings (Bambha et al., 2022). Interestingly, there was also a qualitative shift in how young children approach these play tasks between 12 and 24 months. The youngest children recognized that the goal was to put objects through the opening of the shape sorter; however, they showed little understanding that specific pieces should go in specific openings. Instead, the youngest children attempted to insert each object into the shape sorter opening according to closest proximity, often putting them into a large opening at the top of the shape sorter (intended for removing the objects from the shape sorter). By 24 months, children began to search for the appropriate opening in the shape sorter and were thus more successful. However, even at this age, children's success was limited to shapes that were rotationally symmetrical (e.g., circle, square, hexagon) and could be successfully inserted at many orientations. Between 24 and 48 months, there was an increase in children's ability to insert asymmetrical shapes (e.g., triangle) that could only be successfully inserted at specific orientations. In general, therefore, it appears that even the youngest children recognize the general goal of a toy such as a shape sorter, but their ability to match specific objects to specific openings changes dramatically between 12 and 48 months.

We used data from a second cross-sectional sample to develop a new task to assess mental rotation in children of the same age range (Beckner et al., 2023). Our new task filled a gap in the literature; prior to our task, there were no age-appropriate measures of mental rotation for use with young toddlers through young preschool-age children.  Several features of this task are innovative and novel. Most importantly, the task is tailored to the child's own mental rotation ability. Using an adaptive staircase procedure, children are presented with harder mental rotation tasks (e.g., larger angles of rotation) only if they succeed on previous, easier tasks (e.g., smaller angles of rotation). When children fail at a particular angle of rotation, they are presented with an easier angle. In this way, the task adapts to the child's own level, providing an appropriate challenge on each trial, minimizing both boredom and frustration. We developed both eye-tracking and touch-screens versions of this task. Data collected from a cross-sectional sample demonstrated that most 1-, 2-, and 3-year-old children tested provided evidence of mental rotation, and that older children succeeded at more difficult mental rotation tasks (e.g., larger angles of rotation) than did younger children.

Data were also collected from a longitudinal sample with children between 24 and 48 months of age. Children in this sample were tested twice, about 6 months apart. The goal was to understand how children's mental rotation, as assessed in our new task, was related to memory for objects, fine motor development, and the shift in shape sorter skill documented in our cross-sectional sample. Preliminary results suggest that children's mental rotation in our new task is related to other aspects of development, particularly short-term memory for object features and motor development.

Altogether, the results of this project can inform interventions as well as educational efforts to promote the development of spatial skills, whether it is in considering the most appropriate shapes for a shape sorter for younger versus older toddlers or the highest angle of rotation of an image that may be most appropriate given a child's age. Undergraduate and graduate students as well as lab managers and a postdoctoral fellow participated in all aspects of the project. Several graduate students and our postdoctoral fellow published peer-reviewed articles as first authors. Our lab managers successfully transitioned to PhD programs and our post-doc has accepted a tenure-track position as an assistant professor.
